title: What will be the official U.S. civilian unemployment rate for the month of July 2017?
preds:
https://www.dol.gov/ui/data.pdf
https://data.bls.gov/timeseries/LNS14000000
https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/jobless-claims
https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/continuing-jobless-claims Initial jobless claims reported on 27 July for week ending 22 July went up slightly compared to the previous week (244 vs 233k) but the four week moving average remained the same at 244. This is less than the four week moving average of a month ago, which was 248.5k. Additionally, continuing jobless claims for the week ending 15 July, also reported on 27 July, went down to 1964k compared to 1977 for the previous week.  However, the 4 week moving average moved up slightly from 1959k to 1963.75k. This is quite a bit higher than the average of the previous month, which was 1938k. Taking the two together, it looks like the number of unemployed making claims has increased over the last four weeks, from about 2186 to 2208k.  This suggests an increase in the numerator of July's unemployment rate, but since the denominator can change either way depending on whether people are entering or leaving the workforce, one can't be sure. There'll be one more week of unemployment claims data before the July unemployment rate will be published. To go from June's 4.4% to more than 4.5% would be an increase of 0.2%, which hasn't happened in the last twelve months (though there's been a decrease of 0.2% twice).  An increase to 4.5% is quite likely, but 4.6% would be a surprise.
Junes adnusted numbers were higher than I expected and it seems to be people re-entering tbe work force tbat cancel out job growth.

[8/3/17 update: Oops! Always take note of the challenge closing date!!! Too late to update my last forecast, but based on today's initial claims report for week ending 7/29, predicting UE rate of 4.40% for July; thus higher confidence (95%, perhaps as high as 98%) in a figure between 4.0% plus and 4.5% and lower confidence in a rate of more than 4.5%. But again, monthly figures have some noise to them, plus LFPR could throw a wrench in the model if there are new entrants who haven't been absorbed yet and I don't currently have a model for forecasting participation; thinking 96% and 4% would be reasonable.] Claims for week ending 7/22 are pointing to an unemployment rate in the low 4.4% range, same as prior week and slightly below prediction from 7/8 figures. Easy to put too much faith in point estimates, and the UE rate can easily move by .08% in a single month, so keeping a still-meaningful probability on 4.5%+.
Reaffirming earlier forecast, with a little more confidence.
https://www.zacks.com/stock/news/267800/downward-spiral-in-retail-sales-may-worry-investors-fed "U.S. retail sales fell for the second straight month in June

Moving closer to current consensus after today's initial claims report. Lower claims figure has pulled prediction down slightly, back to 4.42%. Still a bit cautious given how volatile weekly claims figures are, that there's a meaningful probability (based on historic data) for unemployment rate to move far more than 0.8% month to month, and that I don't have a good model for labor force participation rate. There are two more claims releases before July's employment situation reports, will be watching them closely.

https://www.zacks.com/stock/news/267800/downward-spiral-in-retail-sales-may-worry-investors-fed "U.S. retail sales fell for the second straight month in June . . . The dismal sales report overshadowed steady job additions and gradual wage acceleration. . . .  "The rebound in oil prices from all-time lows, decelerating unemployment rate, and a gradual improvement in the housing market signal that the economy is on a recovery mode. These factors are playing a crucial role in raising consumers’ confidence that rose to 118.9 in June from May’s reading of 117.6.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-4692970/US-weekly-requests-jobless-aid-fall-247-000.html#ixzz4mqgaBQGX  "Fewer Americans applied for jobless aid last week, as the number of people seeking benefits has stayed near historic lows pointing to a robust job market. "THE NUMBERS: Weekly unemployment applications fell by 3,000 to a seasonally adjusted 247,000, the Labor Department said Thursday. The less volatile four-week average rose by 2,250 to 245,750. The number of people collecting unemployment benefits has fallen 8.8 percent over the past 12 months to 1.9 million. "THE TAKEAWAY: The job market appears solid . . .  Jobless claims have come in below 300,000 for 123 weeks in a row. That's the longest such stretch since 1970, when the U.S. population was much smaller. "KEY DRIVERS: The economy is expected to grow at roughly 2 percent after a weak start to 2017.  . . . Consistent hiring has helped sustain the gradual recovery, although the expansion is starting to show its age as the pace of job gains has slowed this year. "The unemployment rate has fallen to a healthy 4.4 percent. The Labor Department's report for June showed that U.S. employers added a robust 222,000 jobs, the most in four months and a reassuring sign that businesses may be confident enough to keep hiring despite a slow-growing economy. "In testimony to Congress on Wednesday, Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen took note of several encouraging factors, such as strong job gains and rising household wealth that she said should fuel economic growth over the next two years.
Tweaking based on today's claims data. My model is calling for a gradual increase in unemployment rate, point estimate for end of July is still below 4.5%...but could be very close!

The change from June to July has been consistently 0.0 to 0.1% since 2007 with the exception of a 0.2% increase in Jun-Jul 2008 (https://data.bls.gov/timeseries/LNS14000000). Short of an unexpected major shift resulting in over 100K unemployed with no net gains in the employment rate, this doesn't seem likely to change.

The unemployment rate for June ticked up to 4.4 from May's 4.3. It would need to go up a further 0.2% in July to fall in the "more than 4.5%" category. https://data.bls.gov/timeseries/LNS14000000 The rate has not moved more than 0.1% in any month in 2017, but moved by 0.2% twice in both 2016 and 2015. In 2014 there were 5 months when the rate moved by more than 0.1%, in one case by as much as 0.5%. Taking the last 30 months only i.e. ignoring 2014,, the rate has moved by more than 0.1% on 4 occasions, or about 13% of the time.

Adjusting my unwisely high earlier forecast.
Thank you @matuschoma for drawing my attention to it.

http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-jobs-20170707-htmlstory.html The economy added 222,000 net new jobs, the Labor Department said — the best performance since February and well above analyst expectations. The unemployment rate ticked up to 4.4% from May’s 16-year low, but because more people joined the labor force.
Between June and July the rate only rose by 2% in once (2008) in recent years. Now it's 4,4% so there still is a 1% margin.

Only one report to go and near the high end of 4.0-4.5% bin. Job growth was robust but unemployment went up due to an increase in the labor force. It is hard to imagine the unemployment rate goes below 4.0%, leaving going above 4.5% as the the risk. A move of 0.2% is not unheard of but hard to imagine with good job growth. The labor participation might go up, but it seems a long shot that alone will push the rate above 4.5%.
June figure is 4.4%, up 0.1% from May. Expect rate to remain broadly unchanged in July, with maybe a -0.1%/+0.1% movement at most.

Today's Employment Situation Report makes things interesting with both the participation rate (62.8% from 62.7%) and the unemployment rate (4.4% from 4.3%) up a tenth of a percent. Based on 30-year distribution of one-month changes and potential reactions of current non-job seekers to reports of a tightening labor market, there's now a meaningful chance of seeing unemployment rate at >4.5%. Upping probability to 25%. Base case (75% probability) still 4.0-4.5%.

Labor market remains tight by most measures, although it can be argued that with the participation rate still low versus pre-global-crisis years, some potential slack remains. Seems to me this is essentially a bet on whether we experience a sharp and sudden shock in the participation rate, which would be unusual. Using a model based on initial claims data, I expect unemployment to remain in the 4.3-to-4.5% range in the near term. Consensus is a tad lower at 4.2%-4.4% (Econoday). Putting higher confidence on prediction given that the report is now only about 4 weeks away. Hopefully no major surprises from BLS tomorrow. :)

June data should be forthcoming, but April and May were fairly steady at 4.4 and 4.3, respectively (https://data.bls.gov/timeseries/LNS14000000). Unless there is some major variation in June to skew the numbers, it's likely it will be between 4.0-4.5.
Reduction in immigration, businesses begin to spend their cash reserves.
With no shocks so far, it's likely numbers stay in category 2.
I would put 100% for 2nd category if it was available. Not enough time to get to 3rd or 1st categories.
Shifting heavily toward 4.0-4.5 because the unemployment has been dropping by 0.1 per month on average and I think that keeps up.

It is quite rare that unemployment rate dips below 4% (considered full employment). There is some chance that unemployment rate rises above 4.5% due to seasonal hiring. Between 4 and 4.5% is safest bet.
Currently 4.3%. Only two months until July so it's unlikely to move above 4.5.

The unemployment rate tends to be relatively stable number, with changes often occurring slowly. During the financial crisis it took roughly a full year to reach peak unemployment. For that reason, it seems unlikely that the unemployment rate will escape the current 4.0-4.5% band over the next 2.5 months. The only thing that gives me pause is the knowledge that we are likely at (or at least very close to) the NAIRU, meaning that tail risk is likely somewhat one-sided - it's probably more likely that the unemployment rate will go up rather than down further.

4.3 in May and probably close to bottoming out, though it's hard to say whether retiring baby boomers will out-weight others joining the work force.  The June numbers should give a pointer, but till then it seems unlikely to go below 4.0 or above 4.5

Since fully exiting the great recession in 2014, the civilian unemployment rate has never changed at a rate more than 0.2% in a 1 month period.  The last official unemployment rate was May and the rate was 4.3%.  No major economic disruptions have taken place since President Trump took office and major markets seem to be unaffected by political issues with the Trump administration.    https://data.bls.gov/timeseries/LNS14000000
https://www.bls.gov/charts/employment-situation/civilian-unemployment-rate.htm

Hedging my bet somewhat. Unemployment figure stands at 4.3% for May. Jobless claims have also fallen to a 16-year low, suggestion the economy is close to full employment. For it to drop before 4 would be very unlikely, but possible, given (1) continued low energy costs (e.g. low crude oil prices) and (2) potential legislation to reduce/eliminate financial regulations. Conversely, an unforeseen global event (e.g. Venezuelan default, triggering a worldwide financial panic) could put a halt in hiring and cause an uptick in unemployment. https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-jobless-claims-fell-last-week-1496925115
https://www.wsj.com/articles/house-set-to-pass-bill-rolling-back-wall-street-rules-1496914205
Anfangs wird sie sinken und  dann wird sie im Laufe von Trumps Regierungszeit wieder steigen

When we look at the data from 2007 till now, the change of the unemployment rate between May and July was never more positive than +0.4% (2009) and never more negative than -0.3% (2015). It is now 4.3% to the most likely outcome seems to be between 4.0% and 4.7%.
Raising 2nd category by 5% lowering 3rd category by that amount. Read article about how easily it is for BLS to manipulate numbers. Also short time frame makes the 2nd category more likely.

Only two more data points and the unemployment rate is squarely in the middle of the 4.0-4.5 bin. Typically there is not enough volatility in these numbers to think it is going to deviate from this 4.0-4.5 range. Additionally, the occasions of a US unemployment rate below 4.0 is very rare. It is hard to imagine the economy is so robust as to drop the unemployment rate by 0.3 in the next two months. I see a small chance of an increase in the work force participation rate causing an increase in the unemployment rate to 4.5%.

The figure is at 4.3% per End of May. I looked at the specific seasonal frame (May-Jul)  and found that in the past 30 years, U3 has increased by more than 0.2% only 3 instances (recession years 2001, 2007 and 2008) and never decreased by more than 0,3%. But the trend is heading down so I give a small percantage to a figure below 4% and substract from the probability of U3 coming in higher than 4,5% (I don't see a recession in the making). 
The case for "Between 4.0 and 4.5%, inclusive" has become very solid.
Tightening my forecast band as I don't see the unemployment rate swinging wildly in the next month or so.

April rate 4.4%. In April 2007 unemployment rate went from 4.4% to 4.7% in July 2007. Increasing 3rd category slightly to 30% and decreasing 2nd category to 70%. Side note I'm seeing help wanted and we're hiring signs in front of businesses.

The rate rarely drops by more than 0.1 from month to month, and while we have several months to go from the current rate of 4.4%, job growth is predicted to have "cooled" in May resulting in little-to-no change to that 4.4% figure. As such, unless a major boom or bust occurs, we can expect the unemployment rate to be between 4.0 and 4.5%.
The current trend may get us below 4.5 by July

Taking into account the downward trend + some seasonal influence on the numbers, my forecast for July 2017 is 4.4% ± 0.75% for a 95% confidence interval. So there is some probability that it gets under 4% and over 5%. However: 5% seems to be accepted in the US as "full employment", meaning that everything under this value is to be expected. So it will probably not be so easy to get below 4%.
Adjusting based on latest numbers and trends.
my forecast is based on this previous method for employment numbers.  Plus my forecast for the next few months for the SP500.  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/99758
At 4.4 now so it shouldn't move to far from this level in so short of a time frame.
Labour market is tightening, expect continuation

It is 4.4% in  April, and at this low a level it can easily flatten and bounce +/- 0.2% 
So, it is almost a tie between being 4.5 and a bit lower, versus being over 4.5
Since it is a mite lower now, I'll bias it slightly lower, but will re-visit
Tactically, straying too far from the consensus is to gamble on randomness and "luck".
So far all of Trumps policies are killing jobs not creating them. Especially in the government. I believe it will be more towards 5%

The US unemployment rate has been under 5% for over a year.  Last year's July unemployment rate was 4.9%.  The unemployment rate though in 2017 has not been above 4.8% and has decreased to 4.4% in April 2017.

U3 is already at 4.4% and is projected to continue to decline.
https://data.bls.gov/timeseries/LNS14000000 As labor force participation increases and frictional unemployment creates a natural floor, it is highly unlikely that the U3 will drop below 4.0% America's economy is currently resilient and job additions are net positive each month.  A slow retail market and potenetial tough immigration reform could hurt the U3, hence a 19% chance of it climbing back above 4.5%
https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-u-s-job-market-is-on-a-historic-growth-streak/
U3 on a downward trend, dropping 0.1% per month (starting at 4.8%) since Jan 2017.

First four months of 2017 arithmetic mean is 4.6 +- 0.2. 50% of values are above 4.5 and only 25% are below it.   4.8	4.7	4.5	4.4
https://data.bls.gov/timeseries/LNS14000000

http://www.dailyfreeman.com/general-news/20170505/us-employers-add-strong-211000-jobs-unemployment-44-percent
from the AP wire.  Seems to be inching down at the moment (the unemployment rate, not the AP wire--although as famous purveyors of Fake News, they may decide to duck down, but that's not quite the same thing).

U3 was 4.4% in April 2017. https://data.bls.gov/timeseries/LNS14000000. Expecting possibly one tenth of a percent decrease and then a stabilization at that level over the next few months. Labor force participation is no longer decreasing, which will not help prop up the U3 figure further. http://www.cnbc.com/2017/05/05/heres-the-real-unemployment-rate.html
Unemployment rate decline has slowed to 4.5% in latest month.  Further decline is expected but there's a small chance things might bounce back

Initial claims are bottoming out at levels not seen since the '70s limiting further falls in the unemployment rate but expansionist policies + controls over labour / immigration will keep the labour market tight.
Slow moving number likely to remain within current range.

Average delta from January to July since 1948 (data available) for new presidential term year where a republican succeeds a democrat president equals -0.03%; applied to 2017, July rate would be 4.78%.  Four year moving average of January to July delta is approximately -0.4%; applied to 2017, July rate would be 4.4%.  Less than 4% and 5% or more are based on gut instinct.
The economy improves despite the confusion in Washington.  There is a growing need for people  to fill positions.
The overall outlook is positive. However at or below 4.5% would be an accellerated improvement compared to 2015/2016. Extreme moves beyond the 4-5 range seem unlikely

The key is the word "official." We should not put it past this administration to "win" by changing the definition or flat out lying. That's the only reason I have given a chance to the "less than 4.0%" category.
I predict that this number will just muddle along for a few more months, and not much change will be reported.
Refining my initial base rate toward current employment  rate, and moving toward current consensus.
Check back in May to look at the trend.
The tax plan probably won't pass.
I think over the next few months that the unemployment rate doesn't fluctuate very much or at most continues it's slow downward trend until August.

I had hoped that looking at the seasonally adjusted rate between March and July would help but it does not show a long term consistent trend. Unemployment is already fairly low so I will be looking at a small drop as the most likely.

Looking at the average lengths (in months) of US business cycles from trough to next peak for different subsets gives:
1857- (total): 39 months
1948- (post-war): 58 months
1980- ("great moderation"): 71 months
http://www.nber.org/cycles.html The current cycle has lasted for 93 months (since June 2009), which is the third longest on record. For upper side risk, nothing in the current economic environment suggests the US might be entering a recession in the coming months. Furthermore, unemployment usually follows GDP fluctuation with a lag of a few months, or even one quarter. On the downside, I think the current rate of 4.5 % is very close to full employment, with maybe a few tenths of a percent to be knocked off. The CBO estimates that the NAIRU in Q3 2017 is 4.7 % https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/NROU. 
We have seen sub 4 % unemployment rates in 2000, and in the 1960s, but the effects of growing import competition due to globalization, in particular China's WTO membership, have increased structural unemployment in manufacturing. https://www.econstor.eu/bitstream/10419/69398/1/735446768.pdf This is of course what the current administration want to counter, but the implementation of such policies, not to mention the time it takes for those policies to work their way into the economy, will not have an effect before July 2017.
